description: From earlier randon, from Middle English randoun, raundon, from Old French randon, from randir (“to run, gallop”) (whence French randonnée (“long walk, hike”)), from Frankish *randiju (“a run, race”) or Old Norse rend (“a run, race”), both from Proto-Germanic *randijō, from *rinnaną (“run”, verb), from Proto-Indo-European *(H)r̥-nw- (“to flow, move, run”). Cognate with Middle Low German uprinden (“to jump up”), Danish rende (“to run”). See run.

adjectives.description: random (comparative more random, superlative most random)

entries.meaning: Having unpredictable outcomes and, in the ideal case, all outcomes equally probable; resulting from such selection; lacking statistical correlation.
examples: Synonyms: aleatory, stochastic
The flip of a fair coin is purely random.
The newspaper conducted a random sample of five hundred American teenagers.
The results of the field survey look random by several different measures.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) Of or relating to probability distribution.
examples: Synonym: stochastic
A toss of loaded dice is still random, though biased.

entries.meaning: (computing) Pseudorandom; mimicking the result of random selection.
examples: Synonym: pseudorandom
The rand function generates a random number from a seed.

entries.meaning: (somewhat colloquial) Representative and undistinguished; typical and average; selected for no particular reason.
examples: Synonyms: average, typical
A random American off the street couldn't tell the difference.

entries.meaning: (somewhat colloquial) Apropos of nothing; lacking context; unexpected; having apparent lack of plan, cause, or reason.
examples: Synonyms: arbitrary, unexpected, unplanned
That was a completely random comment.
The teacher's bartending story was interesting, but random.
The narrative takes a random course.

entries.meaning: (colloquial) Characterized by or often saying random things; habitually using non sequiturs.
examples: You're so random!

entries.meaning: (UK, slang) Being out of the ordinary; unusual or unexpected.
examples: That's a rather random fact!

entries.meaning: A roving motion; course without definite direction; lack of rule or method; chance.
(obsolete) Speed, full speed; impetuosity, force. [14th–17th c.]
examples: Synonyms: force, momentum, speed, velocity

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The full range of a bullet or other projectile; hence, the angle at which a weapon is tilted to allow the greatest range. [16th–19th c.]
examples: Fortie yards will they shoot levell, or very neare the marke, and 120 is their best at Random.

entries.meaning: (figuratively, colloquial) An undefined, unknown or unimportant person; a person of no consequence. [from 20th c.]
examples: Synonyms: rando, nobody, nonentity
The party was boring. It was full of randoms.

entries.meaning: (printing, historical) A frame for composing type.
examples: Utilization of all floor space underneath case racks and randoms is another feature of the modern composing room;  […]
